title: Fungal Meningitis
icd10: ** G02 (Meningitis in other infectious and parasitic diseases classified elsewhere)
scope: ** Diagnosis, antifungal treatment, and monitoring of fungal meningitis in adults. Includes cryptococcal meningitis (most common in immunocompromised, especially HIV/AIDS with CD4 <100), coccidioidal meningitis (endemic in southwestern US), histoplasma meningitis (endemic in Ohio/Mississippi River valleys), and other fungal causes (Candida, Aspergillus, Mucorales). Covers induction, consolidation, and maintenance antifungal therapy phases; intracranial pressure management including serial therapeutic lumbar punctures; and immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) management in HIV patients. Excludes bacterial meningitis (see Bacterial Meningitis template), viral meningitis, TB meningitis, and pediatric fungal meningitis.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; leukopenia in immunocompromised; pancytopenia from disseminated fungal infection; pre-treatment baseline for flucytosine (myelosuppressive)
Renal function critical for amphotericin B dosing (nephrotoxic); hepatic function for azole dosing; electrolytes (hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia from amphotericin B)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; baseline Cr, K, Mg, LFTs

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Amphotericin B causes renal magnesium wasting; must supplement aggressively
Amphotericin B causes renal electrolyte wasting
Fungemia detection; Cryptococcus can be cultured from blood in disseminated disease
Fungal blood cultures have higher yield for Histoplasma and Candida; use lysis-centrifugation method (Isolator) if available

Essential/Core Labs.item: Serum cryptococcal antigen (CrAg) — lateral flow assay (CPT 87327)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Highly sensitive (>99%) and specific (>97%) for cryptococcal disease; positive in both serum and CSF; can quantify for treatment monitoring; serum CrAg positive in >99% of HIV-associated cryptococcal meningitis
MANDATORY — cryptococcal meningitis is an AIDS-defining illness; CD4 count determines treatment approach and ART timing; all patients with fungal meningitis need HIV testing
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; if positive, obtain CD4 and viral load

Essential/Core Labs.item: CD4 count and HIV viral load (if HIV positive) (CPT 86360+87536)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: CD4 <100 cells/microL is highest risk for cryptococcal meningitis; guides ART initiation timing (delay 4-6 weeks in crypto to prevent IRIS)
Low procalcitonin helps exclude bacterial meningitis; typically low in fungal infection
Inflammatory marker; typically mildly elevated in fungal meningitis compared to bacterial
Pre-LP coagulopathy assessment; DIC screen in sepsis
Required to calculate CSF:serum glucose ratio; low CSF glucose is hallmark of fungal meningitis
Potential need for blood products; amphotericin B infusion reactions

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Panfungal biomarker; elevated in most invasive fungal infections EXCEPT Cryptococcus and Mucorales (which do not produce beta-D-glucan); sensitivity ~77% for invasive fungal disease
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative (<60 pg/mL); elevated suggests non-Cryptococcus fungal infection

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Aspergillus-specific antigen; sensitivity higher in neutropenic patients; consider if immunocompromised with pulmonary and CNS disease

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Coccidioides serology — IgM and IgG (EIA + immunodiffusion) (CPT 86635)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Coccidioidomycosis screening; complement fixation (CF) titer in CSF is diagnostic of coccidioidal meningitis; serum IgM positive early in infection
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; if positive, obtain complement fixation titer

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Quantitative titer correlates with disease severity; rising titers indicate active disease; declining titers suggest treatment response
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; if positive, titers >1:16 suggest disseminated disease

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Highly sensitive for disseminated histoplasmosis (>90% urine sensitivity in disseminated disease); less sensitive in meningitis alone (~50% in CSF)
Antibody detection; may be negative in immunocompromised; seroconversion takes 2-6 weeks
SIADH assessment (common with CNS infections); monitor with amphotericin B
Identify underlying humoral immunodeficiency predisposing to fungal infections
Cellular immunodeficiency assessment if HIV-negative; low CD4 from other causes (transplant, steroids, malignancy) increases risk

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Culture-negative chronic meningitis; identifies unexpected or rare fungal pathogens; high sensitivity for organisms that are difficult to culture
Suspected CNS aspergillosis; more sensitive than culture; immunocompromised with pulmonary and CNS disease
Rhinocerebral mucormycosis suspicion; diabetic ketoacidosis, neutropenia, iron overload
Blastomycosis in endemic areas (Great Lakes, Ohio/Mississippi River valleys); rare CNS involvement
TB meningitis in differential (subacute, basilar, immunocompromised); CSF profile similar to fungal
Hyperinfection risk if immunosuppression planned; eosinophilic meningitis differential

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated ICP is common in cryptococcal meningitis (>60-70% have OP >20 cm H2O); elevated ICP is the primary driver of mortality; guides need for serial therapeutic LPs
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal 10-20 cm H2O; cryptococcal meningitis often 25-50+ cm H2O; >25 cm H2O requires therapeutic drainage

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Lymphocytic pleocytosis typical of fungal meningitis; WBC count may be low in severe immunosuppression (HIV/AIDS) — paucicellular CSF with positive CrAg indicates poor prognosis
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC 20-500 cells/microL, predominantly lymphocytes; may be <20 in severely immunocompromised

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in fungal meningitis (50-500 mg/dL); very high protein (>500) suggests basilar arachnoiditis (Coccidioides) or CSF block
Lumbar Puncture.target: Elevated (typically 50-200 mg/dL in Cryptococcus; higher in Coccidioides)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low CSF glucose is hallmark of fungal meningitis; CSF:serum ratio <0.4

Lumbar Puncture.item: CSF cryptococcal antigen (CrAg) — lateral flow assay (CPT 87327)
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: GOLD STANDARD rapid diagnostic test for cryptococcal meningitis; sensitivity >98%, specificity >99% in CSF; quantitative titers correlate with fungal burden; serial titers monitor treatment response
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative; if positive, report titer (high titers e.g. >1:1024 indicate high fungal burden and worse prognosis)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Classic rapid test showing encapsulated yeast; sensitivity only 50-70% (lower in non-HIV); largely replaced by CrAg but may be diagnostic if CrAg unavailable
Lumbar Puncture.target: Encapsulated yeast (budding yeast with clear halo); negative does NOT exclude diagnosis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Gold standard for organism identification (grows in 3-7 days for Cryptococcus, longer for others); required for speciation and antifungal susceptibility testing; positive in 75-90% of cryptococcal meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: No growth; if positive — speciation and susceptibility testing

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Exclude concurrent bacterial meningitis, especially in immunocompromised
Rapid multiplex PCR (~1 hour); detects Cryptococcus neoformans/gattii plus 13 other pathogens; useful for rapid differentiation from bacterial and viral causes
Lumbar Puncture.target: Cryptococcus detected or negative; rules out concurrent bacterial/viral pathogens

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in bacterial (>3.5) but variable in fungal; helps distinguish from bacterial meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Variable in fungal (often 2.5-4.0 mmol/L); elevated >3.5 more suggestive of bacterial

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Diagnostic of coccidioidal meningitis; CSF CF titer almost always positive in Coccidioides meningitis; declining CSF titers indicate treatment response
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative; if positive, report titer (any positive CSF CF titer is diagnostic)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Moderate sensitivity (~50%) in Histoplasma meningitis; higher in disseminated disease
TB meningitis has identical CSF profile; must exclude in any chronic lymphocytic meningitis, especially immunocompromised or endemic area
Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis in chronic meningitis differential
Neurosyphilis screen in chronic meningitis differential
Exclude HSV encephalitis if fever with altered mental status

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate — before LP to exclude mass effect; obtain in all patients with altered mental status, focal deficits, papilledema, immunocompromised state
Essential/First-line.target: Hydrocephalus (common in cryptococcal meningitis); mass lesion (cryptococcoma, abscess); basilar meningeal enhancement is NOT seen on non-contrast CT

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h; STAT if focal deficits or altered consciousness
Essential/First-line.target: Leptomeningeal enhancement (especially basilar); cryptococcomas (gelatinous pseudocysts in basal ganglia/midbrain); dilated perivascular spaces (Virchow-Robin spaces); hydrocephalus; ring-enhancing lesions (Aspergillus abscess); basilar arachnoiditis (Coccidioides, Histoplasma)
Pulmonary nodules, cavitary lesions, hilar lymphadenopathy (Histoplasma, Coccidioides); Aspergillus — halo sign; disseminated cryptococcal disease

Extended.timing: Within 48h if chest X-ray abnormal or pulmonary source suspected
Extended.target: Pulmonary cryptococcal nodules; coccidioidal cavitary disease; Aspergillus halo sign or air-crescent sign; hilar/mediastinal lymphadenopathy (Histoplasma)

Extended.timing: If spinal symptoms, radiculopathy, or myelopathy
Extended.target: Arachnoiditis (especially Coccidioides — involves spinal arachnoid); spinal cord compression; epidural abscess

Extended.timing: If rhinocerebral mucormycosis suspected; facial pain, periorbital swelling, black eschar in diabetic or neutropenic patient
Extended.target: Sinus opacification; bony erosion; orbital extension

Extended.timing: If vasculitis or vascular complications suspected (Aspergillus, Mucorales are angioinvasive)
Extended.target: Vessel irregularity; stenosis; aneurysm (mycotic); vascular occlusion
Vessel irregularity; stenosis; aneurysm (mycotic); vascular occlusion

Extended.timing: If altered mental status out of proportion to imaging; suspected non-convulsive seizures
Extended.target: Seizure activity; non-convulsive status epilepticus; diffuse slowing

Rare/Specialized.timing: If diagnosis unclear despite full workup; ring-enhancing lesion of unknown etiology; suspected Aspergillus or Mucorales abscess
Rare/Specialized.target: Fungal elements on histopathology (GMS and PAS staining); culture identification

Rare/Specialized.timing: Suspected rhinocerebral mucormycosis; tissue diagnosis essential for Mucorales
Rare/Specialized.target: Broad non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching (mucormycosis); angioinvasion

Rare/Specialized.timing: Suspected arachnoiditis with spinal cord compromise; MRI contraindicated
Rare/Specialized.target: Arachnoid adhesions; CSF flow obstruction; communicating hydrocephalus

Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.indication: First-line induction therapy for cryptococcal meningitis; fungicidal; liposomal formulation preferred over conventional due to reduced nephrotoxicity

dosing.instructions: 3-4 mg/kg IV daily for minimum 2 weeks (induction); infuse over 2 hours; premedicate with acetaminophen, diphenhydramine, and normal saline 500 mL before each dose to reduce infusion reactions and nephrotoxicity

Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust or switch formulation); anaphylaxis to amphotericin; concurrent nephrotoxic agents (minimize)
Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.monitoring: Renal function (BMP daily); potassium and magnesium twice daily during induction; CBC twice weekly; LFTs weekly; infusion reaction monitoring

Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.indication: Alternative induction if liposomal formulation unavailable; higher nephrotoxicity but more widely available globally (WHO preferred in resource-limited settings)

dosing.instructions: 0.7-1.0 mg/kg IV daily for minimum 2 weeks; infuse over 4-6 hours; aggressive normal saline pre-hydration (1L before each dose)

Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.monitoring: Renal function daily; potassium and magnesium twice daily; CBC twice weekly; rigors, fever during infusion

Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.indication: Combination with amphotericin B for induction; improves fungal clearance and reduces relapse; synergistic with amphotericin B

dosing.instructions: 25 mg/kg PO q6h (100 mg/kg/day in 4 divided doses) for 2 weeks; adjust for renal function (GFR-based dosing); take with food to reduce GI side effects

Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; bone marrow suppression; pregnancy (teratogenic, Category C)
Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.monitoring: CBC with differential twice weekly (myelosuppression — leukopenia, thrombocytopenia); LFTs weekly; flucytosine drug levels if available (target peak 30-80 mcg/mL; toxic >100); renal function daily (adjust dose with declining GFR)

Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.indication: Alternative induction when amphotericin B or flucytosine unavailable (WHO alternative regimen); inferior to amphotericin-based regimens but used in resource-limited settings

dosing.instructions: 1200 mg PO or IV daily for 2 weeks (induction); used with flucytosine if amphotericin B unavailable

Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; QT prolongation; concurrent QT-prolonging medications; pregnancy (teratogenic in first trimester at high doses)
Acute/Emergent — Induction Therapy (Cryp.monitoring: LFTs weekly; QTc at baseline and weekly; drug interactions (CYP2C9, CYP3A4 inhibitor)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nephroprotection during amphotericin B therapy; prevents amphotericin-induced renal vasoconstriction

dosing.instructions: 500-1000 mL IV normal saline infused before each amphotericin B dose

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: I/O; weight; electrolytes; signs of volume overload

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Amphotericin B causes renal potassium wasting in >80% of patients; severe hypokalemia can cause cardiac arrhythmias

dosing.instructions: Replace per institutional protocol; target K >3.5 mEq/L; oral preferred if tolerated; IV replacement for K <3.0 or symptomatic

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Potassium levels twice daily during induction; ECG if K <3.0 or >5.5

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Amphotericin B causes renal magnesium wasting; hypomagnesemia worsens hypokalemia (refractory hypokalemia until Mg corrected)

dosing.instructions: Magnesium sulfate 2-4 g IV over 2-4 hours for Mg <1.5; oral magnesium oxide 400-800 mg daily for mild depletion

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Magnesium levels daily during induction; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Prevents infusion-related fever and rigors during amphotericin B administration

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO or IV 30-60 minutes before each amphotericin B infusion; max 4 g/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Prevents infusion-related allergic reactions during amphotericin B

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg IV 30-60 minutes before each amphotericin B infusion

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Treatment of amphotericin B-related rigors unresponsive to acetaminophen premedication

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg IV PRN for rigors during amphotericin B infusion; avoid repeated dosing (normeperidine accumulation)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Seizure history (lowers threshold); MAOI use; renal failure (normeperidine accumulation)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adjunctive ICP reduction in fungal meningitis with persistent mildly elevated ICP after therapeutic LPs; reduces CSF production

dosing.instructions: 250 mg PO BID-TID; titrate to 500 mg TID if tolerated; monitor for metabolic acidosis and paresthesias

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic or renal impairment; sulfonamide allergy; hyponatremia; metabolic acidosis
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: BMP (bicarbonate, potassium); symptoms of metabolic acidosis; paresthesias

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Acute elevated ICP with signs of herniation (declining consciousness, pupil asymmetry); bridge to therapeutic LP or VP shunt

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus; then 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h; maintain serum osmolality <320 mOsm/kg

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Serum osmolality; osmolar gap; renal function; I/O

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Seizure management if seizures occur; NOT routine prophylaxis; lower drug interaction profile than phenytoin (important with azoles)

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV or PO BID; load 1000-1500 mg if acute seizure; max 3000 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Renal function; mood and behavioral changes

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea and vomiting from elevated ICP, medications (flucytosine, azoles), or meningeal irritation

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV or PO q6h PRN nausea; max 16 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: IRIS management in HIV patients who develop worsening symptoms after ART initiation; NOT recommended as routine adjunct in cryptococcal meningitis (unlike bacterial meningitis — dexamethasone INCREASED mortality in cryptococcal meningitis per ACTA trial)

dosing.instructions: 0.3 mg/kg/day IV (or equivalent) for IRIS only; taper over 2-6 weeks based on clinical response; use ONLY for IRIS, NOT for routine cryptococcal meningitis

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Active untreated infection; GI bleeding; uncontrolled diabetes
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Glucose q6h; GI prophylaxis; BP; signs of infection progression

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: GI prophylaxis during steroid therapy for IRIS; stress ulcer prevention in ICU

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV or PO daily

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: DVT prophylaxis in hospitalized patients with prolonged immobility

dosing.instructions: 40 mg SC daily; start when no active coagulopathy

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Aspergillus meningitis (first-line for CNS aspergillosis); second-line for resistant Cryptococcus; good CNS penetration

doseOptions.orderSentence: Voriconazole 6 mg/kg IV q12h x2 doses (load) IV

dosing.instructions: Load: 6 mg/kg IV q12h for 2 doses; Maintenance: 4 mg/kg IV q12h (switch to PO 200-300 mg BID when stable); target trough 2-5.5 mcg/mL
dosing.orderSentence: Voriconazole 6 mg/kg IV q12h x2 doses (load) IV

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; co-administration with sirolimus, rifampin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital; IV formulation contains cyclodextrin — avoid in renal impairment (GFR <50)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Trough levels (target 2-5.5 mcg/mL); LFTs weekly; visual disturbance assessment; dermatologic monitoring (photosensitivity, squamous cell carcinoma with prolonged use); drug interactions (CYP2C19, 2C9, 3A4)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Alternative to voriconazole for CNS aspergillosis; better tolerated; fewer drug interactions; does NOT require cyclodextrin (safe in renal impairment)

dosing.instructions: Loading: 200 mg IV or PO q8h for 6 doses (48 hours); Maintenance: 200 mg IV or PO daily

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; familial short QT syndrome; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inducers
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: LFTs weekly; hepatotoxicity monitoring; drug interactions (CYP3A4)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Alternative for Histoplasma meningitis (after amphotericin B induction); second-line for Coccidioides meningitis; requires acidic gastric pH for absorption

dosing.instructions: 200 mg PO BID-TID (solution preferred over capsules for better absorption); target trough >1.0 mcg/mL; take solution on empty stomach, capsules with food

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; ventricular dysfunction (negative inotrope); concurrent CYP3A4 substrates
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Trough levels (target >1.0 mcg/mL); LFTs weekly initially then monthly; monitor for heart failure symptoms; drug interactions

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Salvage therapy for refractory Aspergillus or Mucorales CNS infection; delayed-release tablets preferred

dosing.instructions: Loading: 300 mg PO BID on day 1; Maintenance: 300 mg PO daily; delayed-release tablets preferred (consistent absorption)

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Trough levels (target >1.0 mcg/mL for prophylaxis; >1.5 for treatment); LFTs; QTc; drug interactions

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Refractory coccidioidal meningitis not responding to systemic azoles; rarely used due to toxicity; specialist administration only

dosing.instructions: Start 0.01 mg IT; titrate slowly to 0.5 mg as tolerated over weeks; administered via LP or Ommaya reservoir; mix with CSF and inject slowly

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Chemical arachnoiditis symptoms (headache, nausea, radiculopathy); neurological exam after each dose; CSF analysis

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Refractory elevated ICP despite daily therapeutic LPs for >1 week; progressive hydrocephalus; clinical deterioration from ICP

doseOptions.orderSentence: VP shunt or lumbar drain N/A Surgical

dosing.instructions: Neurosurgical placement; VP shunt with programmable valve preferred
dosing.orderSentence: VP shunt or lumbar drain N/A Surgical

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Shunt function; ICP; imaging for shunt position; signs of shunt infection/malfunction

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.indication: Consolidation therapy after successful 2-week induction (Cryptococcus); transition from IV amphotericin B when CSF is sterilizing; 8 weeks consolidation

dosing.instructions: 400 mg PO daily for 8 weeks (consolidation); begin after minimum 2-week induction and clinical improvement

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.pretreatment: Confirm negative or declining CSF fungal culture at end of induction; clinical improvement; able to take oral medication
Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; QT prolongation; pregnancy (teratogenic); concurrent QT-prolonging medications
Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.monitoring: LFTs at 2 weeks then monthly; QTc if risk factors; drug interactions (CYP2C9, CYP3A4 inhibitor); clinical response

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.indication: Long-term maintenance after consolidation (Cryptococcus); prevents relapse; continue until immune reconstitution (CD4 >100 for >3 months on ART with suppressed viral load)

dosing.instructions: 200 mg PO daily; continue for minimum 1 year; in HIV patients, continue until CD4 >100 for >3 months with suppressed viral load; in non-HIV, continue for 6-12 months minimum

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; QT prolongation; pregnancy
Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.monitoring: LFTs q3 months; CD4 count and viral load q3 months (HIV); clinical assessment for relapse symptoms

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.indication: LIFELONG therapy for coccidioidal meningitis; relapse rate near 80% if azole discontinued; never discontinue without ID specialist involvement

dosing.instructions: 400 mg PO daily (standard); 800-1000 mg daily for refractory cases; LIFELONG treatment required — do NOT discontinue

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.pretreatment: Documented Coccidioides meningitis confirmed by CSF CF titer or culture
Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.monitoring: LFTs q3 months; Coccidioides CF titers q3-6 months (declining indicates response); clinical assessment; bone density (long-term azole use)

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.indication: Maintenance therapy after amphotericin B induction for Histoplasma meningitis; minimum 12 months; longer if immunosuppressed

dosing.instructions: 200 mg PO BID-TID for minimum 12 months; itraconazole solution preferred (better absorption); take on empty stomach

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.pretreatment: Completed amphotericin B induction (minimum 4-6 weeks for Histoplasma meningitis); clinical improvement
Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.contraindications: Ventricular dysfunction; severe hepatic impairment; concurrent CYP3A4 substrates
Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.monitoring: Itraconazole trough levels (target >1.0 mcg/mL); LFTs monthly; Histoplasma antigen q3 months (declining indicates response); cardiac function

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.item: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) — for HIV-associated fungal meningitis
Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.indication: DELAYED initiation in cryptococcal meningitis; starting ART too early increases IRIS risk and mortality; initiate 4-6 weeks after antifungal induction therapy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) — for HIV-associated fungal meningitis Per HIV specialist PO

dosing.instructions: Initiate ART 4-6 WEEKS after starting antifungal therapy (NOT immediately); per COAT trial — early ART (within 1-2 weeks) increased mortality compared to delayed ART (4-6 weeks)
dosing.orderSentence: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) — for HIV-associated fungal meningitis Per HIV specialist PO

Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.pretreatment: Completed 2-week induction phase minimum; clinical stability; ICP controlled
Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.contraindications: Do NOT start within 2 weeks of antifungal initiation (IRIS risk)
Disease-Modifying/Chronic Therapies — Co.monitoring: CD4 count and viral load q3 months; IRIS symptoms (worsening headache, fever, meningismus, new focal deficits 2-8 weeks after ART initiation); LFTs; renal function

Referrals & Consults.item: Infectious disease consultation for antifungal selection, treatment duration, and monitoring of drug levels and toxicity
Neurology consultation for seizure management, elevated ICP assessment, and neurological monitoring
Neurosurgery consultation for VP shunt placement if refractory elevated ICP despite serial therapeutic LPs, or hydrocephalus requiring external ventricular drain
HIV/AIDS specialist referral for all HIV-positive patients for ART initiation timing (delayed 4-6 weeks), IRIS management, and long-term immunologic monitoring
Critical care/ICU team for hemodynamic instability, respiratory failure, refractory elevated ICP, or rapidly declining neurological status
Ophthalmology consultation for fundoscopic examination to assess papilledema (indicates elevated ICP); also screen for ocular cryptococcosis and coccidioidal choroiditis
Pharmacy consultation for amphotericin B dosing, flucytosine level monitoring, azole drug interaction management, and renal dosing adjustments
Social work for discharge planning, medication access (antifungals are expensive), insurance assistance, and psychosocial support for prolonged treatment course
Physical therapy for mobilization assessment and deconditioning prevention during prolonged hospitalization
Palliative care for goals of care discussion in patients with severe disease, poor prognosis, or refractory infection

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if worsening headache, new or worsening confusion, vision changes, fever recurrence, neck stiffness, or seizure (may indicate rising ICP, treatment failure, or IRIS)
Do NOT stop antifungal medications without infectious disease physician guidance (premature discontinuation leads to relapse in >50% of cases)
Take fluconazole consistently at the same time each day to maintain therapeutic drug levels
Report any new medications to infectious disease physician before starting (azoles have extensive drug interactions including with statins, certain cardiac drugs, and anticoagulants)
Avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice while taking azole antifungals (increases azole levels via CYP3A4 inhibition)
Coccidioidal meningitis requires LIFELONG antifungal therapy — never stop medication even if feeling well (relapse rate >80% if discontinued)
For HIV patients: take ART medications as prescribed without missing doses; report any worsening symptoms after starting ART (may indicate IRIS requiring treatment adjustment)
Attend all follow-up appointments including scheduled blood draws for drug level monitoring and liver function tests
Use sun protection (sunscreen, protective clothing) while on voriconazole due to increased photosensitivity and long-term skin cancer risk

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Strict ART adherence for HIV-positive patients to achieve immune reconstitution and eventual discontinuation of fluconazole maintenance (CD4 >100 x 3 months with suppressed viral load)
Avoid soil disruption activities (digging, construction, archaeological excavation) in Coccidioides-endemic areas (southwestern US, Mexico, Central/South America) to reduce re-exposure risk
Avoid bird/bat guano exposure, cave exploration, and demolition of old buildings in Histoplasma-endemic areas (Ohio/Mississippi River valleys)
Alcohol cessation during antifungal therapy to reduce hepatotoxicity risk and improve immune function
Adequate hydration (2-3 L water daily if tolerated) to support renal function during and after amphotericin B therapy
Report any skin lesions, bone/joint pain, or pulmonary symptoms that may indicate disseminated fungal disease outside the CNS
Women of childbearing age must use effective contraception during azole therapy (teratogenic — especially fluconazole at high doses and itraconazole)
Smoking cessation to improve immune function and reduce pulmonary infection risk

differential.features: Acute onset (hours to days); high fever; toxic appearance; CSF: high WBC (>1000) with neutrophilic predominance; CSF glucose very low; positive Gram stain
differential.tests: CSF cell count (neutrophils), Gram stain, bacterial culture, BioFire ME panel, procalcitonin (high), CSF lactate (>3.5)

differential.features: Subacute (weeks); basilar meningitis; cranial nerve palsies; CSF profile nearly identical to fungal (lymphocytic, low glucose, high protein); endemic exposure or HIV
differential.tests: AFB smear and culture, TB PCR (GeneXpert), CSF adenosine deaminase (ADA >10), chest X-ray (miliary), QuantiFERON-TB Gold, brain MRI (basilar enhancement)

differential.features: Acute onset; less toxic appearance; CSF: lymphocytic pleocytosis but NORMAL glucose (unlike fungal); protein mildly elevated; self-limited
differential.tests: CSF glucose (normal in viral), BioFire ME panel (enterovirus, HSV-2), procalcitonin (low), CRP (mild)

differential.features: Acute; fever + confusion + seizures + focal deficits; temporal lobe predilection; encephalitis rather than meningitis
differential.tests: MRI (temporal T2/FLAIR), CSF HSV PCR, EEG (PLEDs from temporal region)

differential.features: Chronic meningitis; cranial neuropathies; pupillary abnormalities (Argyll Robertson); CSF: lymphocytic with elevated protein
differential.tests: Serum RPR/VDRL, CSF VDRL (specific but not sensitive), FTA-ABS, treponemal tests

differential.features: Known malignancy; multiple cranial neuropathies; CSF: low glucose, elevated protein; positive cytology
differential.tests: CSF cytology (repeat x3 for sensitivity); MRI with contrast (leptomeningeal enhancement); flow cytometry

differential.features: Chronic headache; cranial neuropathies (CN VII); hilar lymphadenopathy; elevated ACE
differential.tests: Chest CT (hilar adenopathy); serum and CSF ACE; biopsy; PET-CT

differential.features: Subacute; psychiatric symptoms; seizures; often young women; no fever initially
differential.tests: Autoimmune antibody panel (serum + CSF); MRI; EEG; tumor screening

differential.features: NSAID, IVIG, TMP-SMX exposure; self-limited after drug withdrawal
differential.tests: Drug history; CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis with sterile cultures; resolves with drug removal

differential.features: Rodent exposure; biphasic illness; meningitis with normal glucose
Immunocompromised; periventricular enhancing lesions; elevated CSF protein; positive cytology or flow cytometry
differential.tests: MRI (periventricular enhancement); CSF cytology; flow cytometry; brain biopsy

evidence.recommendation: Amphotericin B + flucytosine induction (2 weeks) as gold standard for cryptococcal meningitis
evidence.source: [Day et al. NEJM 2013 (ACTA trial)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23550668/); Perfect et al. CID 2010 (IDSA Guidelines)

evidence.recommendation: Liposomal amphotericin B preferred over conventional for reduced nephrotoxicity
evidence.source: Hamill et al. CID 2010 (AMBITION-cm); [Molloy et al. NEJM 2018 (AMBITION)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29539274/)

evidence.recommendation: Fluconazole 400 mg daily consolidation for 8 weeks, then 200 mg maintenance
Aggressive ICP management with serial therapeutic LPs reduces mortality in cryptococcal meningitis
evidence.source: [Graybill et al. CID 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11498404/); Perfect et al. CID 2010

evidence.recommendation: Delay ART by 4-6 weeks after antifungal initiation in HIV-associated cryptococcal meningitis to prevent IRIS
Dexamethasone NOT recommended as routine adjunct in cryptococcal meningitis (increased mortality in ACTA trial)
Serum and CSF CrAg (lateral flow assay) sensitivity >98% for cryptococcal meningitis
evidence.source: [Boulware et al. Emerg Infect Dis 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24378231/); [Rajasingham et al. Lancet Infect Dis 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28483415/)

evidence.recommendation: Lifelong fluconazole for coccidioidal meningitis (>80% relapse rate if discontinued)
Flucytosine drug level monitoring (peak 30-80 mcg/mL) to prevent myelosuppression
evidence.source: Perfect et al. CID 2010; Expert consensus

evidence.recommendation: Voriconazole as first-line for CNS aspergillosis with trough monitoring (2-5.5 mcg/mL)
WHO guidelines for cryptococcal meningitis management in resource-limited settings
evidence.source: [WHO Guidelines 2022](https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240052178); [Loyse et al. Lancet Infect Dis 2013](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23735626/)

evidence.recommendation: BioFire ME panel for rapid pathogen identification in meningitis
Histoplasma antigen testing (urine) highly sensitive for disseminated disease
1,3-Beta-D-glucan as panfungal biomarker (not elevated in Cryptococcus or Mucorales)
Intrathecal amphotericin B for refractory coccidioidal meningitis
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [Johnson & Einstein. Ann Intern Med 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17283349/)

evidence.recommendation: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) management with corticosteroids

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (GCS, mental status, cranial nerves)
monitoring.frequency: q4h during induction; q8h during consolidation
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT, repeat LP with opening pressure; reassess treatment

monitoring.frequency: Daily therapeutic LP during induction if OP >25 cm H2O; then per clinical status
monitoring.action: If persistently elevated: continue daily LPs; if refractory >1 week, consult neurosurgery for VP shunt

monitoring.frequency: Daily during amphotericin B induction; weekly during consolidation
monitoring.action: If rising: increase pre-hydration; hold amphotericin if Cr >2x baseline; switch formulation; consider alternative regimen

monitoring.frequency: Twice daily during amphotericin B; daily during consolidation
monitoring.action: If low: aggressive IV/PO replacement; do NOT proceed with amphotericin until K >3.0

monitoring.frequency: Daily during amphotericin B; weekly during consolidation
monitoring.action: If low: IV magnesium replacement; correct before treating hypokalemia (refractory K without Mg correction)

monitoring.frequency: Twice weekly during flucytosine therapy; weekly during consolidation
monitoring.action: If cytopenias: check flucytosine level; hold if level >100 mcg/mL; consider dose reduction or discontinuation

monitoring.frequency: 3-5 days after initiation; after dose adjustments; after renal function changes
monitoring.action: If >100: dose reduction or hold; recheck level; if <30: dose increase

monitoring.frequency: Weekly during induction and consolidation; monthly during maintenance
monitoring.action: If >3x ULN: evaluate cause; consider dose reduction; if >5x ULN or symptomatic: hold azole and reassess

monitoring.frequency: q6-8h during first 48h; then daily; q12h in ICU
monitoring.action: If <130: SIADH evaluation; fluid restriction (1-1.2 L/day); if <120: 3% saline per sodium correction protocol

monitoring.frequency: At 2 weeks (end of induction); if clinically indicated
monitoring.action: If persistent positive culture: extend induction by 2 weeks; reassess regimen; consider salvage therapy

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; at 2 weeks; at end of consolidation; q3 months during maintenance
monitoring.action: If rising or stable titer: reassess adherence; repeat LP; consider treatment failure; extend induction

monitoring.frequency: At baseline; repeat LP at 2 weeks (end of induction)
monitoring.action: If not declining: extend induction; reassess therapy

monitoring.item: CD4 count and HIV viral load
monitoring.frequency: At baseline; then q3 months (HIV patients)
monitoring.action: If CD4 not recovering: assess ART adherence; optimize ART; cannot discontinue fluconazole maintenance until CD4 >100 x 3 months

monitoring.frequency: Daily during first 2 weeks of ART; weekly for first 3 months
monitoring.action: If worsening headache, fever, meningismus, new focal deficits: evaluate for IRIS vs treatment failure; may require steroids (dexamethasone) and therapeutic LP

monitoring.frequency: At baseline; q3-6 months during treatment
monitoring.action: If rising: treatment failure; increase fluconazole dose or switch therapy; ID consultation

monitoring.frequency: q4h during induction; q8h during consolidation
monitoring.action: If persistent fever >2 weeks: reassess treatment; repeat cultures; imaging for complications

monitoring.frequency: At 5-7 days after initiation; after dose changes; q1-3 months long-term
monitoring.action: If subtherapeutic: increase dose; check adherence; check drug interactions; if supratherapeutic: reduce dose

disposition.criteria: Completed induction (minimum 2 weeks); transitioned to oral consolidation (fluconazole); ICP controlled without need for daily LPs; neurologically stable; tolerating oral medications; reliable outpatient follow-up with ID and neurology; medication access confirmed; patient/family education on warning signs completed

Confirmed or suspected fungal meningitis requiring IV antifungal induction therapy; hemodynamically stable; GCS >=13; opening pressure manageable with intermittent (not daily) therapeutic LPs; no respiratory compromise

GCS <13 or rapidly declining consciousness; opening pressure >40 cm H2O refractory to therapeutic LP; need for EVD or ICP monitoring; respiratory failure requiring ventilatory support; septic shock; seizures (especially status epilepticus); severe electrolyte derangements from amphotericin B (refractory hypokalemia K <2.5); concurrent severe opportunistic infections in HIV/AIDS
Need for neurosurgery (VP shunt, EVD) not available at current facility; need for ID specialist management of refractory fungal infection; need for neuro-ICU expertise for complex ICP management

Follow-up during consolidation and maintenance phases; serial CrAg titers q3 months; LFTs monthly then q3 months; CD4/viral load monitoring (HIV); medication adherence assessment; azole drug levels; coccidioidal meningitis patients require lifelong follow-up
